title: Fairburn Ings Walk Route

images.title: David Pickersgill / On the boardwalk, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: On the boardwalk. A network of boardwalks, made from recycled plastic, allow visitors right into the marshy area to the west of the main lake at Fairburn Ings RSPB reserve.

images.title: Rod Allday / Village Bay hide at Fairburn Ings RSPB nature reserve, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Village Bay hide at Fairburn Ings RSPB nature reserve. Here you can look out for birds such as bittern, willow tit, kingfisher and grey heron.

images.title: David Pickersgill / Top of Fairburn Cut, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Top of Fairburn Cut. Cut Showing the remains of the wharf where boats were loaded with limestone from quarries near the village, part of which can be seen on the horizon.

images.title: David Pickersgill / View towards Fairburn Ings
images.caption: View towards the reserve. Looking from the top of the limestone escarpment over fields of barley towards the water of Fairburn Ings. The houses on the horizon are Ferry Fryston, an estate in the north-east of Castleford.

images.title: bernard bradley / Newton Ings
images.caption: Newton Ings - on the western side of the site. Southwesterly view from Newton Farm over the flooded ruins of Newton Priory. The chimneys and towers in the distance are the chemical plant in Castleford. The town of Castleford in the far distance.

images.title: David Pickersgill / Newton Priory ruins
images.caption: Newton Priory ruins. Despite its name, it was probably only ever a medieval manor house. This section of wall is all that remains. Note the cormorants.

images.title: David Pickersgill / River Aire and Three Bridges
images.caption: River Aire and Three Bridges. Despite its common name, it's actually one bridge with three arches carrying the Castleford York railway line over the River Aire. Note the swings! Fairburn Ings is behind the tree-covered bank in the right background.

description: This lovely nature reserve in the Aire Valley has some nice footpaths to follow around the substantial site. The reserve includes a number of pretty lakes and nice riverside paths along the River Aire. You can look out for hundreds of different species of birds from a number of bird hides. Habitats in the reserve include flood meadows, wet fenland, marsh and reed bed, woodland and scrub. To continue your walking you can pick up the Wakefield Canal in Castleford and enjoy a waterside walk along the towpath.
